abstracts.cdata!:
Project ratings convey satisfactory
            outcomes, likely sustainability, and substantial
            institutional development impacts. One vital lesson in
            project preparation is the importance of indicators: there
            were no specific outcome indicators established during
            preparation, and appraisal to monitor the progress of
            implementation. However, for the Gewane-Mille road, which
            was included after the Project was revised in 1998, selected
            indicators were identified and a base line established.
            Another lesson drawn from the Project, convey that support
            should be searched from all government entities, to
            facilitate contract implementation, hence minimizing
            bureaucratic procedures, such as delays in customs
            clearance, granting of licenses for explosives and radio
            communication equipment, etc. Also important was the need to
            develop the capacity of domestic contractors, perhaps, most
            important is the recognition of the complexity of
            internationally agreed principles of tendering, questions of
            law in the formulation of contracts, the options for the
            settlement of disputes in direct negotiation to avoid
            litigation, and the tendency towards the use of arbitration.
            This lesson contributed to making special provisions for the
            appointment of dispute resolution experts on all new
            contracts thereafter. Subsequent projects, have incorporated
            arrangements to support capacity in administering
            international contracts, and the domestic construction
            industry. The strengthening of such capacity in this area,
            has contributed to the reduction on contract processing
            time. However, since one of the factors that contributed to
            the delay in implementation was the border conflict, greater
            attention may be needed to the analysis of political risks
            in multinational projects. Of important consideration should
            be the border conflict with Eritrea, where the duty of the
            Government should be to allocate increased funding for
            maintenance, for reducing vehicle operating costs, and
            travel time, possibly through resources to complete the
            project as conceived, as part of post-conflict resolution.
